description: From French mandarinat, corresponding to mandarin +‎ -ate.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The status of holding a position as a mandarin. [18th–19th c.]
The collective body of mandarins. [from 19th c.]
examples: He criticized the monarchy and the mandarinate for failing to save the country and to help the people in their hour of greatest need.

entries.meaning: A political form of rule by mandarins.
(figuratively) A type of government marked by excessive bureaucracy and Byzantine regulations.
examples: Far from being a model of democracy, the EU is associated with an arrogant, out-of-touch mandarinate that issues rules and edicts with paternalistic and highhanded disregard for ordinary citizens.
